**What is this?**

**Excerpt from site:** You know R, especially the dplyr ğŸ“¦. Even though the dplyr ğŸ“¦ is so well written to mimic the SQL syntax - select(), group_by(), left_join() etc. there is still a cognitive load when you switch between using R syntax, and SQL syntax (ask me, who has often written == in SQL syntax on Athena only to wonder why I am getting an error ğŸ¤).

In this tutorial you will learn how to use dbplyr, which is a database back-end of dplyr, to execute queries directly in your RDBMS all the while writing R tidyverse syntax ğŸ˜® â­.
